newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico Cetes rate up on weak peso, other worries.
newsitem.headline: Mexico Cetes rate up on weak peso, other worries.

text.p: Mexico's bellwether one-month Cetes rate rose on Tuesday on a weak peso, political unease and fears the U.S. Federal Reserve could boost interest rates if U.S. employment data come in stronger than expected this week, fixed income analysts said.
At the primary cetes auction, Banco de Mexico assigned 28-day paper at 25.47 percent, 109 basis points higher than last week.

Rates rose across the yield curve, as the three-month paper rate increased 130 basis points to 29.37 percent, and the six-month paper was up 133 basis points to 31.74 percent. One-year paper yielded 32.43 percent compared with 30.94 percent last week.
The hikes were in line with expectations, and were higher in the longer terms on expectations of a U.S. rate hike.
A survey conducted by Reuters of 11 Cetes dealers before the auction found expectations of a 120 basis points rise in the one-month paper rate.
As recently as July 30 the one-month paper was yielding 30.22 percent, but then fell sharply during the first part of August before rising slightly at the auction last week.
"The auction was affected mainly by political noise and by changes in the secondary market," said Luis Cedeno, an analyst with Nationsbank.
Mexican markets have been hit by political unrest tied to attacks by a new guerrilla force in several states last week.
An increase in the yield on the U.S. 30-year bond has also caused fears that rates in emerging markets like Mexico will have to follow.
The U.S. long bond ended the day at 7.06 percent.
"What is affecting us now is the uncertainty over political events and the bond rate in the United States," said one fixed-income market analyst.
The peso pared early losses but still closed with a hefty decline on Tuesday as high U.S. interest rates and political worries spilled into the currency market.
The spot 48-hour peso closed 3.25 centavos weaker at 7.5730/7.5775 per dollar.
"The increase in (Cetes) rates was due to the weakness in the peso and the uncertainty ahead of the U.S. employment data...," said MMS International in a report.
If the employment data are stronger than expected, that could cause the peso to weaken to the mid-7.60 level on fears the Federal Reserve could tighten, the market forecasters MMS said.
